title: Theresa May faces a trio of defeats: Mirror Politics morning briefing
text:
Theresa May is braced for another defeat in the Lords (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Theresa May could have good reason for disliking Tuesdays. 
Today she faces the possibility of a trio of defeats, one in the Commons and two in the Lords. 
Tory MPs believe they have the numbers to force the Government to rethink its plans to halt the Dubs scheme for child refugees. 
Home Secretary Amber Rudd has decided to end the programme after offering help to just 350 unaccompanied children. 
This falls far short of the 3,000 children Labour peer Lord Dubs had hoped Britain would offer sanctuary to. Peers are expected to vote for major changes to the Article 50 Bill 
An amendment by Conservative MP Heidi Allen calls on ministers to find out from local authorities how many children they can help before unilaterally closing the scheme. 
Ms Allen believes she could have the support of as many as 31 Tory MPs, enough if combined with Labour, SNP and Lib Dem MPs to inflict a defeat. 
The Lords is looking to add two amendments to the Article 50 Bil l as it goes through its report stage today. 
One will demand ministers give regular updates to Parliament on the progress of the Brexit negotiations and the other will demand Parliament gets a meaningful vote on whatever deal the Prime Minister comes back with. 
At the moment ministers have promised MPs and peers they will have the chance to approve any “new treaty we agree with the EU” but not if Mrs May carries out her threat to walk away if she cannot achieve a favourable agreement. 
Downing Street argues that giving MPs the chance to send Mrs May back to the negotiating table would play into the hands of the EU negotiators. Stephen Hawking has called for Jeremy Corbyn to quit as leader (Photo: Getty) 
“We should not commit to any process that would incentivise the EU to offer us a bad deal,” No 10 said. 
No 10 may not wish to read today’s report by the International Trade select committee which says that the ‘no deal’ option should be discounted entirely. 
The committee says it would mean falling back on World Trade Organisation rules that would saddle businesses with punitive tariffs on imports and exports. 
A better option, it suggests, is for the UK to join the European Free Trade Association along with Switzerland, Norway, Iceland and Lichtenstein. 
In the Telegraph today William Hague calls for an early election to give Mrs May the mandate she needs as the Government tries to implement Brexit. 
Labour’s weakness at the moment will also be a factor in Hague’s thinking.
